Award.AwardTitle: Application of Transient Time Distributions to Ocean Radiocarbon Records for the Last Deglaciation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Radiocarbon (14C) is an important tracer of ocean circulation. However, although extensive marine Delta14C records have been developed, quantitative interpretations of these records are lacking. The proposed work, led by researchers at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, will take a novel, quantitative approach to Delta14C records of deep and surface waters from the last deglaciation. The project will generate an up-to-date compilation of Delta14C records with associated uncertainty estimates. Transit time distribution (TTD) calculations will be applied to these records to relate deepwater Delta14C concentrations to those in surface waters. Specifically, TTDs derived from modern hydrographic data will be used to compute the changes in deepwater Delta14C that are implied by the surface water records, and vice versa. This approach will test the hypothesis that steep declines in deep and surface water Delta14C values during the last deglaciation were jointly driven by a change in ocean ventilation.

This project will unite the expertise of an ocean modeler, a physical oceanographer, and a paleoceanographer to address a key question about ocean circulation during conditions of deglaciation. A graduate student will be involved in the research, and summer support for an undergraduate student will be provided. Project data, computational software, and accompanying "how-to" documentation will be archived at NOAA's National Climatic Data Center.

POR.DRECONTENT:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

Radiocarbon measurements on fossil biogenic carbonates recovered from the seafloor have been used over the past two decades to draw inferences about the age, and hence the ventilation, of deep oceanic waters during periods of past climate change, in particular during the last deglaciation (between about 10,000 and 20,000 years before present; 10 - 20 kyr BP). The study of ocean paleo-ventilation is a particularly active field of research, often motivated by its postulated effects on atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration and climate. However, interpretations of deep-sea radiocarbon records remain challenging, given the multiple sources of error that can affect these records and the paucity of the current data base by modern standards.

In our project, we have produced a compilation of more than 1300 deep water radiocarbon concentration (Δ14C) data originating from different oceanic basins and spanning the past 40 kyr. An effort has been made to maximize the internal consistency of the assembled data, while satisfying the chronological assumptions in the original publications. The most conspicuous feature in our compilation is a decline in deep water Δ14C over the past 25 kyr in different oceanic basins. The deep ocean Δ14C decline is similar to that observed in the atmospheric Δ14C over the same time interval, suggesting that it may reflect a decrease in the global radiocarbon inventory rather than a redistribution of radiocarbon among different reservoirs.

Motivated by this observation, we have tested the null hypothesis (H0) that the deep water Δ14C records jointly do not require changes in basin-scale ocean ventilation from 20 to 10 kyr BP. To test H0, a quantitative model of modern ocean ventilation has been fit to the deglacial data, and the results of the fit have been analyzed. We have found that (1) the deglacial evolution of deep water Δ14C under H0 is consistent with the deep water Δ14C data given the estimated data uncertainties, and (2) the evolution of surface water Δ14C values under H0 are oceanographically consistent, in the sense that these values do not significantly transgress the bounds provided by contemporaneous values of atmospheric Δ14C and deep water Δ14C. The results (1-2) have been shown to be insensitive to various assumptions in the data analysis, such as (i) the omission of records with particular low Δ14C values interpreted in the literature as being influenced by old carbon emanating from the seafloor and (ii) model architecture. We thus concluded that H0 cannot be rejected with high confidence, given our estimates of the errors in the Δ14C data and the model used.

Importantly, our results do not imply that changes in basin-scale, deep ocean ventilation did not take place during the last deglaciation. Rather, they show that the presently available radiocarbon database appears inadequate to put such changes on a firm ground, given the data uncertainties assumed and the model used. Whether they will still hold as additional deep water Δ14C data become available and more complete ocean models are considered remains to be seen. Additional data would be helpful, not only for better constraining basin-scale ventilation changes (if any) but also for identifying changes on spatial and temporal scales that are shorter than those considered in our project.

 

BROADER IMPACTS

1) Two graduate students from the MIT-WHOI Joint Program in Oceanography have been involved in this project. Ning Zhao has completed most of the tasks of this project under the supervision of its principal investigator (PI, O. Marchal). He has been introduced to numerous facets of this project, has extended the data compilation initially undertaken by the PI, has coded the ocean ventilation model and the inverse procedure used to fit the model to the data, and has analyzed the results to test the hypothesis of this project. He has presented preliminary results at the International Conference on Paleoceanography in Utrecht (Netherlands) and has dedicated a chapter of his PhD thesis manuscript to this project. Finally, he has submitted  a manuscript summarizing his results to a peer-reviewed journal. Graduate student Daniel Amrhein has been engaged in several discussions related to this project, particularly regarding the temporal interpolation of data from deep-sea records, the singular value decomposition, and the whole-domain approach to combine data and models. He is co-author of the aforementioned manuscript.

2) This project has brought together researchers from different background and expertise: paleoceanographer Lloyd Keigwin (WHOI), physical oceanographer Geoffrey Gebbie (WHOI), and data analyst/ocean modeler Olivier Marchal (WHOI). These three scientists have been engaged in an active and fruitful collaboration, and have been associated with various products of this project, in particular with the aforementioned manuscript.

3) The data compilation completed as part of this project has been submitted to the National Climatic Data Center (NCDC) of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Organization (NOAA). It is now publicly available at https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/paleo/study/21390
